node.text:
It's common for people to feel wrist or forearm discomfort while doing bicep curls. If you can relate, it is worth looking into your wrist position while doing bicep curls.
-
The differences that I show in the first slide of this post are very subtle. But if you look closely, you can see that on the left side my wrists are flexed while curling the dumbbells up, whereas on the right side my wrists are straight. The flexed wrists grip puts quite a bit of tension on your wrists and wrist flexors (your forearm muscles), which can result in discomfort.
-
To apply less pressure on the wrists and forearms, straighten your wrists. Maintaining a neutral wrist position helps you focus more on training the biceps and usually also feels more comfortable. If you swipe left and watch the 2nd video of this post, you can see a clear visual. At the start of every set, check whether your wrists are neutral before curling the weight up.
-
Music by @iamryanlittle - Talk To Me via @hellothematic

ðŸ“š This post is another iWannaBurnFat classic, this time covering sugar & fat loss!
-
It's often believed that sugar has no place in a fat loss diet. However, several experimental studies show that when calories are controlled, sugar consumption does *not* decrease fat loss [1-4]. So you can eat sugar and still lose fat, as long as you are in a calorie deficit.
-
That being said, eating a lot ofÂ sugarÂ while restricting your calorie intake is not realistic for most people.Â Sugary foods generally are not the most filling. If you consume a bowl of ice cream, that can cost you ~300-400 calories without filling you up for long. So you may have the urge to eat soon after and this can cause you to overconsume calories. Also, opting for a 300- or 400-calorie meal with whole foods instead will provide your body more vitamins and minerals.
-
So trying to eat a lot ofÂ sugarÂ while being in a calorie deficit is not a good idea. You will probably feel hungry most of the time and your reduced micronutrient intake may not make you feel very good.
-
But if you maintain an overall nutritious diet and have control over your calorie intake, someÂ sugarÂ is not inherently bad. As with most things, moderation is key here. Allowing some flexibility in your diet (in the form of occasional, controlled snacking) is part of developing sustainable eating habits.
-
References:
1.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11093293
2.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/9174485
3.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/11477496
4.Â http://ajcn.nutrition.org/content/65/4/908.long

A few weeks ago, I discussed how abdominal training won't help you spot-reduce body fat But abdominal training can help you develop your ab muscles. Today, I'd like to share a simple progression-model for one of my favorite ab exercises: the side plank.
-
Side planks tend to be a bit more challenging than regular planks. So many people struggle with doing a completely extended side plank when they do this for the first time. If you find extended side planks too challenging, you can start doing side planks with your knees tucked. When your knees are tucked, you have to stabilize less weight and the exercise becomes easier.
-
A logical progression from knee-tucked side planks is side planks with your legs extended. Once you can perform a side plank with legs extended for 25+ seconds, consider weighted planks. You can place a dumbbell on your hip as a way to overload the side plank.
-
I like the side plank because it's simple and easy to overload with the progressions shown in this post. The main training benefit of a side plank is that it trains anti-lateral flexion. This means a side plank helps you better stabilize your spine and prevent it from bending sideways while under load.
-
Music byÂ @iamryanlittleÂ - Seeing Double viaÂ @hellothematic

New YouTube video about deloads is now live! (Visit the link in my bio)
-
It is common for people to make consistent progress on their compound lifts for weeks on end, and then all of a sudden their strength plateaus. If you are not restricting your nutrition and you find yourself in a strength plateau, your problem may be poor fatigue management and you can benefit from having a lighter training session.
-
Strength performance is mostly dependent on your current fitness and fatigue levels [1]. As you train hard for weeks on end, your fitness improves but fatigue also increases. Eventually, you may reach a point at which your fatigue levels increase more rapidly than your fitness [2]. When this happens, your performance in the gym suffers.
-
Having a lighter training session helps by reducing your fatigue. For novice to early intermediate lifters, if your performance on a lift is stagnant for 3 sessions in a row, reduce the load by 10% on the next session and aim for the same number of reps.
-
Having a lighter training session is a form of a "deload." The more advanced you become in your training, the more thought you need to give about lighter training periods. For late-intermediate and advanced lifters, opting for a deload week is likely more beneficial than just 1 lighter training day. In my new YouTube video (link in bio), I cover deloading for experienced trainees. When and how you can deload is covered in detail. So check it out!
-
References:
1. Chiu, L. Z., & Barnes, J. L. (2003). The fitness-fatigue model revisited: Implications for planning short-and long-term training.Â Strength & Conditioning Journal,Â 25(6), 42-51.
2.Â Pritchard, H., Keogh, J., Barnes, M., & McGuigan, M. (2015). Effects and mechanisms of tapering in maximizing muscular strength.Â Strength & Conditioning Journal,Â 37(2), 72-83.

I often get asked how you should approach the holiday season. As with many things in fitness, there is no 1 approach that will work best for everyone. For instance, some people may be very strict and "food-stressed" during the holidays. This person can benefit from being more flexible with their eating. But the opposite is also possible. The type of person that gains excessive weight during the holidays every year benefits from having more control.
-
Based on your past experiences, you know best what your strengths and weaknesses are. Those that are overly strict can try to employ a more big-picture approach to their eating. 1 day of not tracking calories or overeating will not make-or-break your progress. As long as you get back on track afterward.
-
Now, for those that tend to overindulge, having more control over much you eat is beneficial. One method you can make use of is fasting. If you skip breakfast and have a light lunch, you leave yourself a greater "calorie-buffer" for dinner. You can also try to control calories more on the days around an event. For instance, if you know that on Wednesday you'll have a day filled with gatherings, eating less on Tuesday helps.
-
Lastly, it is worth emphasizing that the most important factor is that you enjoy the holiday season. Most people will be able to get by just fine by eating "logically".

The bicep has two heads, a short (inner) and long (outer) head. No matter what bicep curl variation you use, the short and long head work together to accomplish the movement. You can't "isolate" one head. But it still may be possible to put slightly more focus on one region of your bicep over the other.
-
If we look at the anatomy of the two bicep heads, we see that the long head of the bicep crosses the shoulder joint. Because of this, the long head of the bicep is placed at a more lengthened position when you perform bicep curls while your arms are behind your body. So based on the length-tension relationship of muscle, the long head of your bicep needs to work slightly harder during exercises like incline bicep curls.
-
On the other side, when you keep your arms in front of your body (e.g. preacher or spider curls), the short head of your bicep will need to take on more of the work. This is because the long head of your bicep will be more shortened and won't be in a favorable position to maximally contribute to the movement.
-
So you can change your bicep exercise selection based on which part of your bicep you would like to focus on more. Keep in mind that this is just a small detail. Make sure you get the basics of training right first (progressive overload, training with enough volume, consistency etc.) before worrying about minor things like this.
- 
Music byÂ @iamryanlittleÂ - You'll Be Okay viaÂ @hellothematic

ðŸ“š This post is an iWannaBurnFat Classic! Specifically for those going on an extended holiday trip or can't train due to injury.
-
You may have heard of the term "muscle memory". Even though your muscles technically don't have a memory (duh lol), muscle memory refers to how it's relatively easy to regain the muscle you lose due to inactivity [1].
-
Muscle memory works because you retain the nuclei you acquire as a result of lifting weights, even when you take a long training break [2]. Nuclei are essentially the control centers of your muscle fibers. Acquiring new muscle nuclei allows for more muscle growth to occur [3].
-
So even though you may lose some muscle when you stop training for several weeks, the muscle nuclei you retain make it possible for you to regain lost muscle quickly. When you swipe left, you can see a visual description of how muscle memory works.
-
It's important to remember though that muscle loss won't occur quickly in the first place. Current evidence indicates that muscle loss starts to occur after a 2-3 week training break [4, 5]. But if for some reason you need to take a long training break, it's always good to know that you have the potential to regain lost muscle quickly.
-
References:
1.Â https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-20287-3
2.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26792335
3.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2930527/
4.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28328712
5.Â https://www.researchgate.net/publication/259390281_Evidence-Based_Resistance_Training_Recommendations_for_Muscular_Hypertrophy

If you perform different deadlift and squat variations, you are pretty much training every major muscle group in your legs. But if you want to focus specifically on training your glutes, it is beneficial to include a thrusting/bridging exercise like the hip thrust.Â Today, I'd like to discuss a common mistake with the hip thrust, which is overly extending your spine.
-
You want to keep a mostly flat torso while performing the hip thrust. If you overly round your back at the bottom or even at the top of a hip thrust, you'll stress your low-back more than needed and take tension away from the glutes. As you see in the video, I also keep my chin slightly tucked and the pelvis in a slight posterior tilt position with the "correct form". Keeping the chin slightly tucked and the hips in a slight posterior tilt help with maintaining a mostly flat torso.
-
Hip thrusts are particularly effective for the glute because you maximally load the glutes while you are at full hip extension. Although exercises like squats and deadlifts also train hip extension, minimal tension is placed on the glutes once you stand upright.Â This helps explain why research indicates that a hip thrust targets the glutes more effectively than a back squat [1].
-
If you want to give the hip thrust a try, perform 3 sets of 6-10 reps 1-2x/week.
-
Reference:
1.Â Contreras, Bret, et al. "A comparison of gluteus maximus, biceps femoris, and vastus lateralis electromyographic activity in the back squat and barbell hip thrust exercises." Journal of applied biomechanics 31.6 (2015): 452-458.
-
Music by @iamryanlittle - airplane mode. via @hellothematic

The bench press is a staple exercise in most strength training programs. Oftentimes people wonder whether they should perform a barbell or dumbbell bench press. In today's post, I'll compare the two and show you how they can be combined.
-
BARBELL PRESS: This is arguably the most popular bench press variation. In this variation, both arms work together to push the barbell up. Because of this, the flat BB press has relatively low joint stability requirements and you can push heavier weights compared to a dumbbell bench [1].
-
DUMBBELL PRESS: Since each arm holds up a dumbbell, each arm is trained individually on the DB bench press. This is great if you want to fix or prevent a muscle imbalance. But because each arm is trained individually with a free weight, the DB bench press is less suited for very low rep ranges (1-5RM) since it's hard to stabilize the heavy dumbbells.
-
Both barbell and dumbbell pressing are similarly effective and have their own benefits and drawbacks [2]. I'm personally a fan of combining both barbell and dumbbell benching to get the best of both worlds. The way I combine them is by doing flat barbell bench in a lower rep range while using DB incline pressing in a 10-12 rep range to focus more on targeting the clavicular (upper) head of your chest. Swipe left for visual examples!
-
References:
1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21225489
2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27100318

As long as your diet puts you in a calorie deficit, you can lose fat without doing any cardio [1]. But that does not mean cardio is useless. Doing cardio a few times per week can help you lose more fat by increasing your energy expenditure. The next obvious question is, what type of cardio is best? Should you do HIIT or moderate-intensity cardio?
-
When it comes to losing fat, there is no 1 type of cardio that is inherently more effective than the other. A 2017 meta-analysisÂ gathered data from 31 studies to analyze whether high-intensity cardio provides a fat loss benefit over moderate-intensity cardio (while calorie-burn is matched). No significant difference in fat loss between HIIT and moderate-intensity cardio was found [2].
-
So if you want to increase fat loss via cardio, you have flexibility as to what type of cardio you should do.Â If you are short on time, high-intensity cardio is a great way to burn calories in a short period of time [3]. But if you already train with weights several times per week, moderate-intensity cardio (up to 3x/week) is less demanding on your body and may interfere less with your recovery from lifting weights.
-
For athletes, it is also important to consider that the type of cardio you do impacts the type of adaptation your body goes through.Â When you perform mostly high-intensity cardio, you train your ability to exert maximum effort and have a high-force output. When you do low- to moderate-intensity cardio, you mostly get endurance adaptations. Based on your training goals you can pick a cardio modality.
-
References:
1.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10838463
2.Â http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/obr.12536/full
3.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18362686
-
Music by @helloitsmrchase - Grace & Mercy via @hellothematic

You may have heard ofÂ theÂ sayingÂ "you areÂ theÂ result of your small daily efforts. It's theÂ (oftentimes subconscious) actions you perform day-in-day-out that made youÂ theÂ person you are today.Â TheÂ same holds true for fitness. 1 cupcake does not make someone overweight. TheÂ snacks in between meals, not training after work,Â theÂ drink every night, and many more small actions added together are at blame.
-
So if you want to change course in your health and fitness,Â we need to focus on replacingÂ the smallÂ daily actions that are holding you back with more favorable (but still realistic!) actions. This is where setting "action goals" comes into play.
-
Far too often people are solely focused on an outcome goal like "losing 30 lbs of fat". It's okay to have an end-goal in mind. But to achieve that goal, your main concern should beÂ theÂ behaviors that slowly lead to fat loss (for instance: controlling your portions, training 3-5x per week, sleeping well etc.). Try to create a system that eventually leads you to your objectives.
-
Since you may start making New Year's resolutions soon, consider this while writing down your goals. Next to having an outcome goal, also set specific action-goals that you can realistically execute.

TheÂ BulgarianÂ splitÂ squatÂ is one of those exercises that most people have a love/hate relationship with. It's extremely effective for training lower body strength & balance, but it's also quite fatiguing. Still though, it's one of my favorite lower body exercises.
-
If we compare theÂ BulgarianÂ splitÂ squatÂ with the backÂ squat, we see that theÂ BulgarianÂ splitÂ squatÂ generally puts a bit more focus on the glutes and hamstrings, whereas the backÂ squatÂ is more quad dominant [1, 2]. But this will also depend on how you perform the split squat. The more perpendicular your shins are to the floor (vertical shin position), the more you'll train the glutes/hamstrings.
-
But the foremost reason I like split squats are the movement benefits.Â Many people struggle with balancing themselves while standing on one leg. It's also common to have a dominant leg that is considerably stronger than the other. Split squats help improve single-leg stability and correct any strength imbalances. Exercises like walking lunges have the same benefit.
-
Now, you may be wondering, so how can I combine squats and split squats in my training routine? And what if I also want to do deadlifts? If you swipe left 3x, you can see a practical training idea of how you can incorporate squats, split squats, and deadlifts into the same workout program.
-
References:
1.Â McCurdy, Kevin, et al. "Comparison of lower extremity EMG between the 2-leg squat and modified single-leg squat in female athletes." Journal of sport rehabilitation 19.1 (2010): 57-70.
2.Â Jones, Margaret T., et al. "Effects of unilateral and bilateral lower-body heavy resistance exercise on muscle activity and testosterone responses." The Journal of Strength & Conditioning Research 26.4 (2012): 1094-1100.
-
Music by @iamryanlittle - Think About You via @hellothematic

If you consistently lift weights, there are 3 main types of adaptations your body goes through: Neuromuscular, Muscular & Connective Tissue adaptations.
-
First, we have neuromuscular adaptations. Your body recognizes movement patterns and becomes more efficient as you perform certain movements consistently. Say, for example, you often practice the squat. Eventually, your nervous system adapts in a way that it can recruit more of your lower body muscle fibers and activate these fibers more frequently.
-
Rapid gains in neuromuscular efficiency is oftentimes the reason why beginner trainees can gain strength relatively quickly without gaining much muscle [1]. But there's only a limited amount of strength you can gain without gaining actual muscle size. This brings us to the 2nd adaptation: muscle growth. As you consistently overload your muscles, eventually they'll increase in size [2].
-
The last one is connective tissue (tissue that attaches muscle to bone) adaptations. Your tendons and ligaments strengthen if you lift weights properly. Overall bone health seems to increase as well [3]. This helps explain why there's good research showing that training with weights can relieve low-back pain and arthritis-related discomfort [4].
-
All in all, lifting weights gives you more than just "muscle gains." You can also expect general improvements in your everyday movement [5].
-
References:
1.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17053104
2.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15335243
3.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19453205
4.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/m/pubmed/22777332/
5.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17762377

There are multiple ways through which a protein-rich diet helps improve your fat loss results. First of all, high-protein diets are more effective than low-protein diets for maintaining muscle [1].
-
In one 2010 study, the researchers had 2 groups of resistance-trained athletes [2]. Group 1 maintained a protein intake of 2.3g/kg of their total body weight, whereas group 2 maintained a protein intake of 1g/kg BW. As you can see in the 2nd slide of this post, the group with the higher protein intake maintained significantly more muscle. So protein basically helps you stay jacked while dropping body fat.
-
Although the research lately has been mixed on this, protein generally also helps you feel more satisfied while dieting [3].Â A classic example of this is a 2005 study [4].Â When the participants increased their protein from 15 to 30% of daily calorie intake, hunger decreased and their calorie intake dropped. But not all protein sources are equally filling. Liquid protein sources like shakes may not make you feel very satisfied [5]. Opt for solid protein sources higher in volume.
-
Lastly, a common question I receive whenever I post about protein, is whether there is a "protein limit" per meal. Oftentimes people think the human body cannot absorb more than 30g of protein. But this is not the case. In my new YouTube video (link in bio), I discuss the "protein absorption myth". I also give practical recommendations on how much protein to have per meal. Check it out by visiting my YouTube channel: iWannaBurnFat.
-
References:
1.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6566799/
2.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19927027
3.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23107521Â 
4.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16002798
5.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/31706311

Everyone has abdominal muscles hiding behind their abdominal fat. Oftentimes the only thing that's separating you from your six-pack is a good fat loss phase.
-
But abdominal training still can be useful. Next to the core stability benefits you obtain, it's also possible to grow your abdominal muscles with consistent core training.Â We know the abdominal muscles basically to stabilize your body. SoÂ exercises that involve stabilizing your trunk (like planks, cable wood chops etc.) are goodÂ options.
-
Just consider that, like any other muscle, the abdominal muscles need progressive overload and training with sufficient volume to develop. Using weighted ab exercises makes it easier for you to make consistent progress in your ab training.Â If you swipe left, you can see 2 example exercises I use when I want to focus more on abdominal growth.
-
I want to add some notes about the first exercise shown, the cable ab pulldown. In this exercise, you want to keep your shoulder blades spread apart and focus on flexing your spine. This may sound counterintuitive, but spinal flexion is one of the main functions of your rectus abdominis. As long as you use a weight that's manageable for you, this exercise is safe to perform for healthy individuals. The cable wood chops showed 2nd help you focus more on oblique training.
-
If you want to focus more on developing your abs, start by performing 1-2 weighted ab exercises about 2-3x per week.
-
Music byÂ @iamryanlittleÂ - Seeing Double viaÂ @hellothematic

Many of the questions I get related to fat loss are about carbohydrates. Some people have the idea that you must have a low-carb diet to lose fat. But that's not the case.
-
A 2017 research review gathered the findings of 32 highly controlled nutrition studies [1]. The review found no significant fat loss differences between high-carb and low-carb diets. This was while matching calorie and protein intake.Â Theories like the "insulin-obesity" hypothesis that oftentimes are used to make people believe carbs are the enemy have been refuted multiple times [2, 3].
-
For the active individual, there are actually benefits when it comes to eating carbs. For one, carbohydrates can improve your training performance [4]. Stored carbs in the form of muscle glycogen is a main fuel source during high-intensity training [5]. Next to this, many nutritious foods tend to be high in carbs. So if you completely restrict carb intake, it becomes harder to get a wide variety of micronutrients.
-
Now, if for some reason you thrive on a low-carb diet and are enjoying it, continue the good work. But if you currently are on a low-carb diet and are hating it, you don't have to restrict your carbs. As long as you keep your nutrition controlled (by limiting your calorie intake), you can lose fat on a moderate-to-high carb diet.
-
References:
1.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28193517
2.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28765272
3.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28074888
4.Â https://jissn.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/1550-2783-7-7
5.Â https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/02640414.2011.574722

Pre-exhausting your chest by performing flyes immediately before the bench press is often believed to increase chest activation. A few studies have put this to the test and found that not your pectoral muscles, but the triceps are activated more if flyes are performed before benchingÂ [1-3].
-
A logical explanation for this is that fatiguing your chest forces secondary muscle groups (triceps in this case) to take over when you perform a compound lift. So unless you'd like to increase the activation of secondary muscle groups during a movement, pre-exhaustion isn't going to benefit most people since it generally impairs performance [4].
-
If you use pre-exhaustion to "feel" your muscles work more during training, you probably can achieve the same effect by just performing a few high-quality warm-up sets. If doing chest flyes before benching feels good to you, try incorporating chest flyes (not taken to failure) in your warm-up routine.
-
References:
1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19855317/
2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18076251/
3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27984499/
4. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4763829/
- 
Music by @skeetonthebeat - Late Night via @hellothematic

Today, let's discuss fitness & aging. Just because you are a middle-aged individual, doesn't mean it's too late to take control of your health and improve the way you look. But there a few differences compared to younger individuals that are worth noting.
-
Likely the most important difference when it comes to muscle growth is anabolic resistance. As you age, the anabolic response to strength training and protein consumption decreases [1, 2]. This can negatively affect recovery from training. Also, the older someone is, the more "wear-and-tear" usually is present from training and everyday activity. Because of these factors, older individuals may not be able to handle as much volume as their younger counterparts.
-
But still, this should not be discouraging. Regardless of age, there is always progress to make and the research support this. A 2009 study found that middle-aged (35-50 y/old) and college-aged (18-22 y/old) males gained similar muscle when they followed the same program [3]. Other research shows that 60+-year-olds can still gain slight muscle and strength with consistent training [4].
-
Next to gaining muscle, lifting weights is also a good treatment for age-related losses in muscle quality (sarcopenia). By challenging your muscles with strength training and paying more attention specifically to your protein intake, you can slow down many of the negative physical effects associated with aging [5].
-
References:
1.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26784225
2.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2670034/
3. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19387379
4. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3117172/
5.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4849483/

A lack of time or energy is oftentimes seen as an obstacle to achieving fitness results. But being more healthy and physically fit is not an "all-or-nothing" game. Doing something, no matter how small the effort, is almost always better than doing nothing.
-
Let's take the example of protein's effects on fat loss. Research shows that having a relatively high-protein diet helps you lose fat and maintain muscle more effectively whileÂ in a calorie deficit [1, 2].Â But if for some reason you struggle with getting enough protein in a day, you can still achieve good fat loss results on a low- to moderate-protein protein diet if you just control your calorie intake.
-
The same holds true with training. If you can't train 3-5x per week, that does not mean your training efforts are wasted. There is research showing beginner trainees can gain strength while training just 2x per week [3]. So tailor your fitness based on your current capabilities. You want to prevent giving up completely.
-
There's a popular saying that goes: "A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush." Basically, sometimes it is better to stick with what you have/can do instead of trying to do more and potentially ending up with nothing. As you gain momentum in your fitness journey, you can always intensify things to challenge yourself more.
-
References:
1.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4258944/
2.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4478942/
3.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8267700

The one-arm DB row is one of the most common back exercises used. With a few simple cues, it is quite easy to perform.
-
As you can see in the video on the left side, when the stabilizing leg on the floor is too close to your upper body, your back could start rounding a bit. You want to place the stabilizing leg that's on the floor slightly behind your body so that you can maintain a mostly straight back.
-
When you pull the weight up, focus on pulling your elbows back. This is a goodÂ cue for most back exercises. See your lower arm merely as a "hook" that attaches the weight to your elbows.
-
The one-arm DB row is a good alternative to bent over or T-bar rows that I have discussed in previous posts. If for some reason your low-back hurts when doing bent-over rows, one-arm dumbbell and chest-supported rows are great!
-
Music byÂ @helloitsmrchaseÂ - Summer Rain viaÂ @hellothematic

Every time I write a post related to how fat leaves the body, people are surprised reading this!Â Contrary to popular belief, you do not sweat or "poop out" most of your body fat. Based on the calculations of a 2014Â research paper, 84% of the fatÂ you lose is turned into carbon dioxide and leaves your body through your lungs by breathing [1].
-
The remaining 16% becomes water, which can be lost in many ways like sweat, urine or any other bodily fluid. This basically means that actual "fat loss" primarily occurs when you breathe. So don't hold your breath! ðŸ˜‰
-
In all seriousness though, before this gets misinterpreted, fat loss is still the result of a calorie deficit. If you consume fewer calories than your body expends in a day, your body burns mostly fat for energy. It's just that the way this fat leaves your body is mostly via breathing.
-
In my new YouTube video (check the link in my bio!), I teach you all about how you can create a calorie deficit to achieve long-term fat loss. No complex formulas. Just a simple explanation on why a calorie deficit is important and how you can create a deficit for fat Visit my YouTube channel: iWannaBurnFat
-
Reference:
1.Â Meerman, R., & Brown, A. J. (2014). When somebody loses weight, where does the fat go?.Â Bmj,Â 349, g7257.

There is good evidence on mental imagery and sports performance [1]. By visualizing yourself performing a certain movement before actually doing it, you can mentally practice the motor skills involved in a certain lift.
-
Let's take the squat, for example. Instead of just putting a bar on your back and lifting the weight up/down, most people can benefit from actively thinking about "how" you will squat. Visualize the way you unrack the bar, how you will go down, essentially visualizing your desired squat form.
-
Visualizing how you will perform a movement, likely will help you master the form a bit better. Since you may have improved technique when making use of mental imagery, your lifts are also more efficient and this can benefit strength performance. As an example, in a 2012 study, researchers found that mental imagery helps improve leg press performance [2].
-
Now, to make the mental imagery effective, it's a good idea to mimic the conditions you're in when performing a task. So you can do this in between sets and/or during your warm-up to mentally prep yourself for lifting weights.
-
References:
1.Â Richter, J., Gilbert, J. N., & Baldis, M. (2012). Maximizing strength training performance using mental imagery.Â Strength & Conditioning Journal,Â 34(5), 65-69.
2.Â Lebon, F., Collet, C., & Guillot, A. (2010). Benefits of motor imagery training on muscle strength.Â The Journal of Strength & Conditioning Research,Â 24(6), 1680-1687.

AÂ deadliftÂ is a great exercise that targets a variety of muscle groups. It trains almost the entire posterior chain. Muscles like the hamstrings, trapezius, spinal erectors, lats, and many more are active duringÂ deadlifts. But theÂ deadliftÂ isÂ a complex exercise, many people struggle withÂ deadliftÂ form.
-
Today, I want to share a simple cue about bar positioning on the deadlift. In order to lift the bar up in the most efficient way possible, the barbell needs to be over your midfoot (around your shoe-laces, where your center of mass is). If you place the bar in front of your midfoot, you'll notice that you need to "yank" the bar up with your low-back to get into the starting position.
-
Even though the deadlift is oftentimes deemed as "dangerous", if executed correctly it provides movement benefits. In one 12-week study, a 3-day strength training program that included common lower body exercises like lunges andÂ deadlifts helped alleviate low-backÂ painÂ and increase low-backÂ strength in the participants [1].
-
So doing free-weight lower body exercises like theÂ deadliftÂ and doing them right can benefit you in the long run!
-
Reference:
1.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27900136
-

We eat food to fuel physical activity and life. But inÂ this day and age, it's no longer realistic to look at food solely as "fuel" for the body. Food is also part of mostÂ cultures and people's social life [1]. To put it in technical terms, we eat food for physiological and psychosocial reasons [2, 3]. Whether this is a good or bad thing is up for debate, but it's certainly important to acknowledge.
-
This is why a diet that on paper is "optimal" for producing fat loss may not be the best diet for you. If you can't stick to a certain nutrition approach because of your lifestyle, you won't be able achieve the benefits. How well you can stick to your diet is one of the best predictors of fat loss success [4].
-
So consider your individual lifestyle factors (like time availability, stress, social life, career etc.) when designing a fat loss diet that puts you in a calorie deficit. There is no 1 "best approach" here. A nutrition approach that's sustainable for someone that works 9-5 may be terribly impractical for someone working night shifts.
-
References:
1.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3426439/
2.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3930879/
3.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3086895/
4.Â https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5618052/

Although the title of this post states "bad gym day", I think you only have a bad gym day if you skip a planned workout. Even if you weren't able to perform at your best on a certain day, you still showed up and are building the habit of consistently going to the gym.
-
Now, to make sure that when you are in the gym you make the most of your time, let's look into some variables that could impair your performance. First of all, we have stress & sleep.Â A 2014 study by the University of Texas found that chronic psychologicalÂ stressÂ negatively affects energy levels and impair muscle recovery [1]. A 2018 research review shows that not sleeping enough for days on end also impairs muscle strength performance [2]. So if for some reason you feel less strong in the gym, it may be related to your stress and/or sleep.
-
Hydration is also important to consider. One research review suggests that athletes should prevent fluid loss of more than 2% of total body weight for performance [3]. For most people, simply drinking according to your thirst will put you in the right hydration ballpark [4]. But it can't hurt to carry a water bottle with you if for some reason you forget to drink throughout the day.
-
Lastly, it of course also is possible that you are undereating. If you are in a severe calorie deficit, you may notice your energy levels go down. But also if you just restrict carbohydrates you may not a decrease in performance. This is because carbs are an important fuel source for high-intensity exercise[5]. So if you start a low-carb diet, it is possible you feel less strong when lifting weights.
-
